item.title: DIY:Online tutorials
item.description: All these materials are the effort of great people working hard to make their work available to everybody. If you like any of you see below, please send them an email thanking them for their work. Training team at Harvard Chan Bioinformatics Core: hbctraining(at)hsph.harvard.edu Jeff Oliver: jcoliver(at)email.arizona.edu Sean Davis: twitter: @seandavis12 - https://seandavi.github.io Basics Introduction to Shell - training team at Harvard Chan Bioinformatics Core. Introduction to R - training team at Harvard Chan Bioinformatics Core.

item.title: DIY:PILM tutorials
item.description: We develop some tutorials to fit the PILM community, here you will find a list: Basics - PILMBC103 Best practices on remote storage and computing systems PILMBC104 Best of R Intermediate - PILMBC211 Best practices on RNAseq analysis I PILMBC211 Best practices on RNAseq analysis II Advance -

item.title: Pipelines with Nextflow
item.description: Supported pipelines in OpenMind for PILM community. Full pipelines We use Nextflow to run our pipelines. Our pipelines are in our GitHub repository with the naming: pipelines-ng-*: RNAseq pipeline: https://github.com/pilm-bioinformatics/pipelines-nf-rnaseq For instance, to run the RNAseq pipeline you can do the following (assuming you have nextflow already): nextflow pilm-bioinformatics/pipelines-nf-rnaseq -prodile docker,test If you want to run the development pipeline: nextflow pilm-bioinformatics/pipelines-nf-rnaseq -r pilm-devel -prodile docker,test To know the difference, look at the CHANGELONG file: https://github.
